intro: Scolopia coriacea, commonly known as rough scolopia, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States and parts of Mexico. It is characterized by its woody stems and lance-shaped leaves that are covered in a rough, textured surface. The plant produces clusters of small, yellowish-green flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Scolopia coriacea is often found in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to thrive in arid conditions. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton.
